reviewText:
So, I played this entire game through from start to finish. I was really looking forward to playing this game, because I am a fan of the actual roleplaying game. To say the least, I was thoroughly disappointed.

The game suffers from lighting errors early in the game, which already establish a bad image for the rest of the game. The annoying lighting errors aside, the actual graphics of the game aren't horrible, but aren't impressive either. I recall some texture errors on armors, in which a glitchy texture covered the entire armor set. In addition, I also recall many of the armor models being reused, so  quite a few of the armor sets look the same.

The actual game play is accurately described in the description as, hack and slash"

reviewText: Although it is certainly possible to glean some enjoyment from this game, it is impossible to pretend that it isn't a huge failure in every way imaginable. Like nearly every D&D title not adapted by Black Isle Studios and/or BioWare, it is an affront to all the grand-daddy of RPGs stands for. It is a barely customizable linear hack'n'slash with a wonky camera, unintuitive targeting and unresponsive controls.\nNote also that both the develepor and the multiplayer platform, Bedlam and GameSpy respectively, are out of business. So neither support nor dungeon-crawling with strangers are an option.

reviewText: I've tried to come back to this game a few times now but just can't seem to stay interested.  Not sure if it is the simplistic story or the silly way in which the NPCs just grunt at you while the dialogue comes at you (reminds me of a Nintendo game actually), but I just haven't been able to stick with the game long enough to finish it.  Combat mechanics are ... meh, and you are forced to pick from a mostly premade character with no ability to really create your own character which is also disappointing considering this is a D&D game.\nKind of felt like Gauntlet-ised D&D.

reviewText: I would rate this game a 5/10. A lot of reviews would have you think it's the worst game in the world. That isn't true, it's just the worst D&D game I've come across.\n\nThe game suffers from so many flaws it's hard to put them all in words. The combat and camera is wonky. The writing isn't good. The graphics weren't anything special even in 2011. Yet, here I am 4 years later playing through it for a second time. It has a pseudo-Dark Alliance vibe to it that can be an okay diversion for 5-6 hours. At the end you'll probably end up wondering why you didn't spend those hours playing something--no anything--else.

reviewText: I definitely seem to be in the minority with this game, but I really enjoy it.  Other than an odd bug that happened towards the end of the game when my primary and secondary weapon buttons on the mouse got reversed and I couldn’t change them back, I never really experienced any problems.  Is the game the greatest thing since Swiss cheese?  No, but if you can get it on sale, I think it’s definitely worth it.  I just finished my first play through with the fighter and plan to go back and try someone else.  Don’t go in expecting the world and you will definitely get your money’s worth of enjoyment.

reviewText:
Technically a mess. Had to edit an INI file to fix textures. Had to edit an INI file to set resolution. Kerning issues. Ending sucks. Got trapped by NPCs and had to start a mission over.

Still liked it.

Music and atmosphere are solid. Combat feels good. Skill tree is decent. Was sort of bummed when it was over. Worth a play if you like the genre.

reviewText: I've tried three times to play through this, only making it to the end on my final attempt. This game is poorly written and very buggy. Half the equipment does not load textures properly, so expect to be clad in nasty blue if you want the best equipment. The ending was so bugged that I read several articles and watch multiple YouTube videos on how to get it to complete, and I still couldn't finish. I could beat the final boss, but the game would always crash before it would save my victory. This game is just awful. It captures none of the magic of Dungeons and Dragons. Stay away. Free is too much to pay for this game. You'll never get the life you waste on it back.

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game but with it just comes off as really uninteresting and slow. I admit, I've spent very little time with this game but every time I try it, I can barely get past the tutorial. The graphics are very dated, and though skills and things look fun, trying to play this with a mouse and keyboard seems like they didn't really want it played that way.
voteText: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Finished it years ago and neglected to review it - like most games in my account. Not as bad as some say, in my opinion, but probably not the best either. Lower your expectations (if you ignored the negative ratings) and you might actually have som fun. Strange minor bugs once in awhile but nothing gamebreaking that I know of or experienced personally. No major technical issues either. I actually liked Daggerdale, despite its shortcomings, and I still do. My biggest complaint would be the fact that you cannot remap your keys without some tweaking in the ini or through the use of software such as autohotkey. Very annoying even though I got it to work in the end.

Also, the current price for it is likely a bit steep. The game is abandoned so there are not going to be any official fixes for whatever you might bump into while playing. Have to check the internet or forums for that.

6/10

reviewText: To be perfectly honest I wish there was a way to have a null vote, that aside. D&D: Daggerdale is plagued by bugs and glitches. Most predominant is when wearing the majority of magically imbued armours your character will tend to tun into a grey and blue/purple thing. I can't say I'd recomend a game that allows such a thing to occur, particularly with a $14.99 price tag. The good points of the game, well, aside from being few and far between, is that it actually follows the 4th edition ruleset that it is based off, instead of dodging around a lot of the rules.\nThere are too many bugs, glitches and things that need to be fixed before this game would be really worth paying $15 for, were it to be fixed, it might actually be make a name for itself, though I am doubtful that such a thing will occur.

reviewText:
D&D:Daggerdale is simple hack and slash combat. Not alot of story or in depth world here to explore. The combat is simple and straightforward, at times too easy and other times kinda challenging (depends on level,enemies and numbers). Multiplayer and more world/areas/dungeons is what would have made this game a lot more fun.

cons: no in-game chat to communicate , short game without much replayability.

reviewText: I find DnD:Daggerdale a fun game. I've played DnD table top and it has a lot of same builds. The controls are easy nothing to hard or complex. and at for the price its a steal. The story line is good and the game play is fun. The only down side is you can't make your own char. You can only pick from a Mage Halfling, Elf rogue, Human Fighter, and Dwarf Cleric. I wish they would have let you build your own. This game is still worth play. I recommend it the game not hard so it could dull the game play later on. But it just really sucks you can make your own Char. That really kills the fun for me.

reviewText: Dungeons and Dragons: Daggerdale is a short, mostly easy game that can be completed in under 10 hours. It has a multiplayer option that is powered by Gamespy, and as of this writing on 29/12/2013 one can create a new account and play through online multiplayer with other players (though it does take a few tries). For what you get I'd generally only recommend buying this game when it's on sale. It's just not long enough to justify the higher price tag.

reviewText:
An excellent simulator of being a sentai member accidentally marketed as a Dungeons & Dragons game, D&D: Swordville is a delightful game to spend a little time playing, especially for those who enjoy accidentally selling off their entire inventory when attempting to scroll down a merchant's inventory list.

Considered a game of the year 2011 by such respectable institutions as Wikipedia and Metacritic, this is a title definitely worth picking up if you find it on sale for at least $20 off the cover price.

(Note: I haven't beaten this game and likely will not until/unless I try it on a different computer, because it started crashing on startup after my first two play sessions and has continued doing so ever since. That... pretty well fits with how well the game was working before that, but still.)

reviewText: For when it was released only two years ago, this game is shockingly laking in basics, e.g. voice work.  Embarassing grunts and groans with text replace proper voice work.  It is the first game for years that I have bought in a sale for less than a fiver and still felt robbed.\n\nIt plays and looks like a sort of single character version of Dungeon Siege but even then doesn't have that classic feel.  I would rather reload Dungeon Siege: Legends of Aranna than play this anymore.  If Steam had an Amazon-like section Game for Laptops" it might belong there....."

reviewText: Bland And Boring: Daggerfail is what they should've called this. There, I summed up the game in an amusing way, if I do say so myself (I'm hilarious, what can I say). Ok, let me explain some more. The graphics aren't that bad, but they ARE bland and the faces are ugly as hell. It's like I'm looking at people with down syndrome (no offense meant). Add some (and now I'm being generous) bugs and glitches and NO FUN whatsoever and this game is the result. I normally love dungeon crawlers, but the combat is clumsy, as well as the interface. The loot is crap. NPC's are (or get) stuck in environments and objects, (solved) quests aren't always triggered, the camera swirls around so much that it disorients me and I could go on and on and on. But it's just not worth it. Leave it be.\n\n[Rating: 52/100]

reviewText: This is not a very good game.  It isn't balanced at all for single player, the characters are a bit too one dimensional and inadequate to face the number of enemies that will be encountered at a time.  I didn't run into any serious bugs while I played but during cut scenes the game has a very aggravating habit of teleporting the character around, moving you to a different position so that you may be a bit disoriented when you regain control of your character and on occaision it will have back to back reloads of a level when you complete a quest.

The graphics are decent and the game play style is not frustrating, but that is about all this game has going for it.\n\nThere are only four characters you can be, and they are already built for you, allowing for extremely limited customization (simply put, you choose your spells/abilities and that is it).  The story is also less than enthralling, which is one of the biggest reasons this gets my thumbs down.  Any game based off of the world of Dongeons and Dragons, be it the Forgotten Realms or some other D&D world, should have much more thought put into the story.  All together this title is one I would recommend against buying at all.  If it is ever free to play, then perhaps it will be worth the money.

You know what I recommend about this game?\n\nDon't buy it. It's crap. Even on sale it's crap. Seriously, this is crap. There is NOTHING D&D here besides a thin veneer of stats" that as far as I can tell don't do ♥♥♥♥. If it was fun despite that I'd write a different review. It's crap. Cannot emphasize that enough. It's crap."
avoid
Disappointing! Character creation is unbelievably boring, story looks to be pretty linear so far. Don't buy...

I...really...REALLY can't tell people to buy this, rather all I can do is say to STAY AWAY. It's a very buggy, glithy game where multiplayer conncets and disconnects at it's own will, visurals fliker in and out all the time with missing textures, and the combat doesn't offer much in the way of tatics or skill...Honestly if your looking for a fun group beat-em-up/dougion crawler...Titan Quest would be better, PSO for as old as that is would be better, Classic 'Gauntlet' would be pretty much damn better and more fun then this.

This game has a headache-inducing camera, character movement is a bit awkward, interface is bad, skills are limited (may be a 4e thing, not sure), you're locked in to stock race/class/stat combinations with little customization, gameplay seems repetitive (mind you, didn't manage to force myself to play too far in) although isn't terrible, and the cutscenes and voice acting is awful. Except for a nice cutscene of an earth elemental at the end of the tutorial (which the game doesn't allow you to fight anyway), all the cutscenes in the introduction scene (with no backstory to speak of, too), and first hour of the game are still photos - every dwarf you speak to brings up an identical portrait of a bedraggled dwarf, and a voiceover of a single bemused grunt from stock sound libraries no matter what the dwarf is trying to say.\n\ntl;dr: Sadly awful.

Just bought this game when it was on sale, glad I did not pay full price for it because I feel like I just wasted my money. Controls suck and there is no way to change or edit them! How can I play a game when I can't even control my character properly?

Bleh.  The characters are boring and set, no real customization.  The story was boring compared to what you'd expect from a D&D game.  The graphics glitched with different armor sets.  I'd get a new helmet and put it on and the character would turn purple.  I typically love games like  Diabo, and Neverwinter Nights and such like that, and this game does nothing close to it.  Its a waste of however much money you paid for it.  Its crap.  WOTC should do themselves a favor and ditch this title before it tarnishes their good name.

Hack & Slash, but with less flavor. If you like that sort of thing and you're honest about just wanting to kill creepy-crawlies in mines, go ahead. Otherwise this is pointless and it sucks to play single-player.

Not even Close to a proper D&D Title. Though i didnt mind the action hack n slash implement, it was not fluid enough to maintain the role play aspect of what D&D has been about all these years. Ive seen 1 patch for the game come up and it still didnt fix the Large GFX issues; i.e. broken armor textures, or even the save and exit while in the middle of a quest. Doing so does not save your quest progress but instead saves everything else and makes you start the quest from the begininning.\n\nI do not wish to bash a D&D series over one mishap child in the series, but i do would like to call out a Development team that really needs to gather background information on a Series before they start their own off-series title.
A bit too generic and simple for my taste.

Its a Crawl game but i had to re play it to find what i did not like (LOL) to long ago , its the respawn if one of the main rooms that was frustrating to use needed cures  for this room every time you go in it
As an introduction to the simplified hack n' slash world of 4th ed D&D, it works. As anything else, it fails.
Don't waste your money.
This game has several technical glitches, sub-part voice acting and the combat was very basic. Not worth buying.
10 words: this game is the most repetitive grind of all time

This game feels like it fell out of the 90s. Character creation is limited to selection of 4 different preset race/class combinations. The UI is not very intuitive (scroll bars that only allow the top and bottom arrows to be clicked?) and the game's maximum resolution is hard-coded, instead of being able to match your monitor (1920x1080p? Not happening)\n\nYou'd have to really be a fan of 4th edition DND to make this worth $15. Fanbois only.
Did not enjoy it at all. Controls were awkward, gameplay was boring, quests were pointless.

I was told the game was bad going into it, but it was far worse than I imagined. I played Mystery of the Druids through to completion, because it was so terrible it wrapped around to interesting. This I couldn't stand to play more than 20 mins of.
Utterly terrible. Too bad, I hoped it would be good. Lousy graphics, horrible controls, and annoying that if you die you have to repeat like 3 hours of gameplay because you can't save.

Despite how fun this game looks, it isnt. Forced into a Race/class combo (without letting you even choose most of your stats!) this is a Diablo rip off, and not a good one at that. On top of the lactluster gameplay, There is a lack of complete voice overs except at the end of chapter (Grunts for everything else). The flaws dont even end there Skellies taking full damage from swords and arrows and ghosts are able to take damage from everything regardless if its a magical weapon or not. Every thing with special texture also is bugged, it is replaced by a Blue and White texture, and has been since release of the game (Unless you enjoy running from Gargamel, this is a bad thing). All and all it is not worth the 15 dollars spent on this game. Burning your money would give you more enjoyment and a closer experiance to DnD then this game could offer (Fire is ALWAYS fun). This recommendation is more of a warning. Dont buy this game unless you want to be extremly disapointed.

This is a horrible game.

I say this because there was so much potential but this game dishonors the name of Dungeons and Dragons.

The gameplay is awkward and buggy and does not feel fluid. This game feels like it was made fast for a quick sale and not enough thought was put into the player and how they would receive the game.

I really want to be able to reccomend this game.  It has so much potential that is wasted.

The largest problem, is lack of support / fixes.  The texture issue is quite annoying, running around blue and white because your armor doesn't have a texture.

The final boss fight was a bit annoying as well, being so different from the rest of the game.

The game is also very short.  You can finish it in one sitting.  And the ending, just feels like it was the end of chapter one and there is no chapter two.

The game play is hack and slash action RPG.  Nothing wrong there.  Has potential, that just seems wasted.
I bought this game thinking: Oh nice
recommended: will be fun." I have never been more wrong in my life. It is very hard to describe this game without using cusses. It is utterly bad in any possible way. It is repetitive
voteText: has a story with the complexity of a Fast & Furious movie and does absolutely nothing to entertain the poor human soul that has started to play this garbage game. I would rather burn my computer than ever touching this *thing* again in my life."

reviewText: Not what I was hoping for. Might be fun for a casual gamer.

A console version of Baldurs Gate, and in no way is this a good thing. 3rd person hack and slash with a D&D stamp meant to bring RPG to the console but failing at every turn. Contrived and cliched story telling, poor game play and repetitive combat, this is one game to avoid.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

Character customization is non-existant. You have the choice of 4 pre-generated character archetypes - halfling wizard, elven rogue, human fighter and dwarf cleric.

There isn't even a point-buy system for stats, they are fixed.

The controls are unwieldy and completely counter intuitive, you are also unable to customise them, at least during the tutorial.

As for the storyline, I don't know if it's good or not as I couldn't bring myself to complete the tutorial. I was so frustrated by the interface and also disappointed by the lack of customisation.

Worst game ever, makes me ashamed I own it. Horribly buggy with constant crashes, graphics glitches, and quest fails which render progress impossible. D&D rules are loosely implemented as vague flavoring for an action RPG clickfest. Also, very painfully obvious it's a console port with poor conversion to keyboard/mouse. Be prepared to juggle three areas of the keyboard plus both mouse buttons for numerous and pointless quick-time event sections, which probably map better to a console controller.\n\nIf this game were an old-school pen and paper D&D session, I'd have already flipped the table and punched the DM in his stupid mouth.

This is the first PC game I'd owned since Baldur's Gate II (which was amazing 15 or so years ago).  I tried to play this game a couple of days and was like what the f__K? this sucks compared to Baldur's Gate!"  Then
date: since I'd played Morrowind on XBOX
recommended: I immediately went out and bought an old disk copy of Oblivion
hoursPlayed: downloaded a female body replacer for it
voteText: and felt infinitely better about the world and my place within it."

reviewText: dis game sux balls
sadly this game sucked.... we need a GOOD dnd game

Very repetitive game. Played for a few hours, but I didn't leave the dungeon where I go from one menial task to the next.\nExpected a change of environment or captivating story, but it seems to have none of it.
Awful. It's buggy, slow, and is a complete middle finger to D&D Fans.
Utterly terrible. Too bad, I hoped it would be good. Lousy graphics, horrible controls, and annoying that if you die you have to repeat like 3 hours of gameplay because you can't save.

The gameplay is awkward and buggy and does not feel fluid. This game feels like it was made fast for a quick sale and not enough thought was put into the player and how they would receive the game.

The final boss fight was a bit annoying as well, being so different from the rest of the game.

to be honest at time ether it feels to hard or to tidious ether way could have been better even more so since it's a dungeons an dragons which deserves better

After reading the reviews and playing the game for about an hour I had no idea, what on earth were all these people complaining about. Just another hack'n'slash, some minor bugs and a bit crude graphics, I've seen worse.

Oh wait, no, I haven't.

Imagine a cave with 4 corridors. Small ones. Boring ones. You will spend the entire first chapter (I'm assuming they're of similar length, so 1/3 of the game) in these 4 corridors. Tempting? Yeah, to me neither...
♥♥♥♥♥♥ single-player-MMO-esque cashgrab. Look elsewhere for your D&D RPGs.

I assumed D&D games couldn't dissapoint me, but Daggerdale entirely disabused me of that kind of thinking. A shallow intro sequence foreshadows an even shallower story. The well known AD&D rules system was flattened to the ground and the flame of motivation was doused when i saw myself confronted with 4 bound by class and race characters. Movement felt kind of clumsy, while simple graphics with no love for details made me reconsider my buying decision.
Terrible controls. Why would you trying to reinvent the wheel? It's so unintuitive that I couldn't play more than an hour.

Hack & Slash, but with less flavor. If you like that sort of thing and you're honest about just wanting to kill creepy-crawlies in mines, go ahead. Otherwise this is pointless and it sucks to play single-player.
Terrible controls. Why would you trying to reinvent the wheel? It's so unintuitive that I couldn't play more than an hour.

Save your money, this is one of the worst adaptations of the beloved pen and paper game I have ever seen. If you do decide to purchase this and invest any amount of time into it, prepare to smash more barels than donkey kong.

I did not enjoy this game much at all.  It is based on the 4th edition of Dungeons and Dragons and really lacks alot of variety.  I would say its worth the money, but I think I'd rather have the cash.

Personally, I feel this game seems like it was a rush job when I've played it. No options for voice chat when they have voice chat in the game. Saw a post on the forums and apparently it's powered by GameSpy Arcade? Something that seems non-existent? Some of the armor does not have proper graphics, so as the dwarf, one could say I look like a Smurf. Yup, a blue and white character model.

If one truely wants this game, I would only buy it if it was dirt cheap. Friend of mine got it to me for free, played it with him, felt like it was a waste of my two hours.

It does have potential if they would actually fix all the crap within it, but considering when it was released (June '11) and when I posted this (Jan '12), I doubt any progress has been made.
A bit too generic and simple for my taste.
Console-esque á la Demon Stone" and "Dragonshard" games - not really an RPG
date: but a hack-n-slash with little to no character progression/upgrades...\n\nIf I'd known that before buying
recommended: I'd have passed....even at the 75% off price :("

reviewText: This game is TERRIBLE.  Do not purchase this game, not for 8 dollars.  Certainly not for 15 dollars.  Don't even pick this game up if it goes up on sale for 2-5 bucks.  It's an incomplete mess.  It's boring, and it's not even worth it if you're just looking for a good ol' fashioned dungeon grinder.  Fire up Diablo 2 again, or go out and buy Torchlight.

This isnt a recomendation its a warning!

The Controls are clumsy at best between character movement and Camera control, the game progresses you along without warning and can move you to the next step making you run back to collect anything you didnt get or whatever you wanted to do before hand.

Character creation is a Joke, if they would have allowed a more varied creation such as a dwarven rogue or a Human Wizard it would have been easier to overlook the control aspect. As it stands your pretty much locked into the feats" you take because you have no real control over character creation.

I would give this a 2.5 out of 5 rating because it has potential but it failed at reaching it!"
Don't waste your money.

Dungeons and Dragons: DaggerFAIL

This game is a port from the Xbox Live Arcade version of the same game. It feels like it'sa game that's been  in Alpha testing and then they've just decided to release it as a joke.

The game advertises it's 4-player co-op, however you are unable to connect to any Multiplayer games. There is absolutely no options in the lobby so you just have to sit and wait, and hope someone else can connect to your game. Trying to join someone elses game presents the same issues. I can only imagine that the game is so horrible no-one else is playing it.

So stuck playing 1P. First item I received was a helmet. I equipped it, and it had no textures. The controls are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. The 'cutscenes' that tell you what's supposed to be going on in the game are jerky and disjointed. Sound = horrible. When you click the button the guy swings his weapon. This is about the only thing that actually works.

This is just about the worst game I've ever played. $15 down the drain...

Don't bother with this game.  For something released in 2011, it sure feels and looks like the early 2000s.  I guess the DnD license can just be used by anyone to create terrible games nowadays.

The graphics are horrible, the music is awful, and the gameplay is mediocre.  Instead of actually having voiced lines, someone decided to just give all the conversing characters grunts instead of actual words.  Textures in the game kept failing on me and the only reason I bothered beating it was... well I don't know.

Random loot drops is the *only* thing the game had going for it.  Nothing else.  This is definitely one of those play and uninstall as quickly as possible" types of games.  Don't even bother looking back.

Rating: 2/5 (Just barely)"

Buggy game that apparently hasn't gotten much support since it was released years ago. It wouldn't be a bad time killer if it wasn't technically deficient. I have had equipment textures not load leaving my character striped white and purple. I have had trouble changing video settings (they seem to revert when I exit the menu). If I'm not mistaken this was ported from console and not very well.
Might be a good game someday, but for now wait till its patched :D
Did not enjoy it at all. Controls were awkward, gameplay was boring, quests were pointless.

I was told the game was bad going into it, but it was far worse than I imagined. I played Mystery of the Druids through to completion, because it was so terrible it wrapped around to interesting. This I couldn't stand to play more than 20 mins of.
Utterly terrible. Too bad, I hoped it would be good. Lousy graphics, horrible controls, and annoying that if you die you have to repeat like 3 hours of gameplay because you can't save.

The graphics are decent and the game play style is not frustrating, but that is about all this game has going for it.\n\nThere are only four characters you can be, and they are already built for you, allowing for extremely limited customization (simply put, you choose your spells/abilities and that is it).  The story is also less than enthralling, which is one of the biggest reasons this gets my thumbs down.  Any game based off of the world of Dongeons and Dragons, be it the Forgotten Realms or some other D&D world, should have much more thought put into the story.  All together this title is one I would recommend against buying at all.  If it is ever free to play, then perhaps it will be worth the money.

I normally try to be forgiving with a game's shortcomings but this one is pretty bad. It has DX11 but the engine won't go beyond 720p or at the most 1600x900 and even then I'm not convinced it doesn't revert because when I go into options it shows that its reverted. The graphics were mediocre at best and the camera angles were mostly useless. Definitely one to skip.

There is NOTHING D&D here besides a thin veneer of stats" that as far as I can tell don't do ♥♥♥♥. If it was fun despite that I'd write a different review. It's crap. Cannot emphasize that enough. It's crap."

so i would recomend it.. but since it has so many many many bugs and some ppl cant even play it i wont.

The graphics are decent and the game play style is not frustrating, but that is about all this game has going for it.\n\nThere are only four characters you can be, and they are already built for you, allowing for extremely limited customization (simply put, you choose your spells/abilities and that is it). It has DX11 but the engine won't go beyond 720p or at the most 1600x900 and even then I'm not convinced it doesn't revert because when I go into options it shows that its reverted. The graphics were mediocre at best and the camera angles were mostly useless. Definitely one to skip.

The only thing good about this game for me was that I 'won' a contest and got a free copy.  I think I was probably the only one to enter...

Just another terrible d&d title.  I don't think we've had a really good one since the Infinity Engine days.  Temple of Elemental Evil was ok once the devs released unofficial mods.

This one?  Terrible attempt at pushing a stripped down 4e ruleset...wasn't even turn-based like the real rules.  Terrible textures, wonky controls....not a great experience.
This game really stinks, or at least it did when I played it.

I had fun playing this game with my friends at the start, but that soon changed. The lag set in the A.I started to glitch. If that wasnt bad enough a shield somehow got douplicated in my inventory 46 times and there was no way of deleting, dropping or selling them so there was nothing I could do....
OHHH so much potential, for so much nothing.

DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME!!!!

Steer clear of this game.  The game is bugged in many areas, in fact one cannot complete the game to to the bugs.  In addition Bedlam Studios, the company who made the game, has went under and provided a press release stating that there will be no upcoming patch to correct the fundamental flaws in the game.  So please, save your money for something else.

I would give this game 1 (one) star out of a possible 5 (five) and that's only because it carries the name Dungeons & Dragons.
Terrible game. Mindless grind. Mediocre graphics. No character customization. No voice acting, just grunts and text boxes. Avoid like the plague.

This game represents the industries most ill-programmed and poorly thought out games.  It is a veritable lump of crap, with no redeeming qualities.  Don't buy- and avoid, like the plague.
It's not D&D if you just beat on everyhting until it explodes into gold and experience points.

Worst game ever, makes me ashamed I own it. Horribly buggy with constant crashes, graphics glitches, and quest fails which render progress impossible. D&D rules are loosely implemented as vague flavoring for an action RPG clickfest. Also, very painfully obvious it's a console port with poor conversion to keyboard/mouse. Be prepared to juggle three areas of the keyboard plus both mouse buttons for numerous and pointless quick-time event sections, which probably map better to a console controller.\n\nIf this game were an old-school pen and paper D&D session, I'd have already flipped the table and punched the DM in his stupid mouth.

Not even Close to a proper D&D Title. Though i didnt mind the action hack n slash implement, it was not fluid enough to maintain the role play aspect of what D&D has been about all these years. Ive seen 1 patch for the game come up and it still didnt fix the Large GFX issues; i.e. broken armor textures, or even the save and exit while in the middle of a quest. Doing so does not save your quest progress but instead saves everything else and makes you start the quest from the begininning.\n\nI do not wish to bash a D&D series over one mishap child in the series, but i do would like to call out a Development team that really needs to gather background information on a Series before they start their own off-series title.
Not much of a story, not very exciting gameplay.

I didn't like the top down approach to the game and I disliked that it wasn't really a party oriented playstyle. To me, the core of D&D games is and should be the party, which this game seemingly doesn't have at all.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

Character customization is non-existant. You have the choice of 4 pre-generated character archetypes - halfling wizard, elven rogue, human fighter and dwarf cleric.

There isn't even a point-buy system for stats, they are fixed.

The controls are unwieldy and completely counter intuitive, you are also unable to customise them, at least during the tutorial.

As for the storyline, I don't know if it's good or not as I couldn't bring myself to complete the tutorial. I was so frustrated by the interface and also disappointed by the lack of customisation.
Got is as a bundle played for a few hours.  Inistalled
I can't believe I spent money on this. STAY AWAY!
